report_title: Industry Research: Hospital Construction in the US
executive_summary: The industry has encountered challenging conditions, with revenue falling at a CAGR of 1.2% to $28.5 billion over the past five years, despite a bump of 4.9% in 2023 alone. Hospitals have met a high degree of fiscal uncertainty via to the whittling down of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) from the prior administration, while a renewed focus on it by the Biden administration has already boosted the number of health-insured consumers, bolstering demand for hospital construction. From legislative hurdles to the global pandemic outbreak causing construction stoppages amid a surge in demand for hospital capacity, the industry has endured significant volatility.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Industry Was Somewhat Paralyzed During a Period of Surging Demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The industry has encountered various challenges, though none have been as problematic as healthcare reform legislation's uncertainty. There has been a shift from large, traditional hospitals to small local care centers for nonemergency situations. The pandemic outbreak disrupted industry operations due to local and state-mandated work stoppages and limited capacity for essential construction. As regulations eased in 2021 and macroeconomic conditions improved, the industry was rejuvenated amid surging health expenditure by the federal government, and the servicing of pent-up demand from 2020 enabled industry revenue to soar.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: THE PATIENT PROTECTION AND AFFORDABLE CARE ACT (PPACA) RESTRUCTURES INDUSTRY OPERATIONS
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: PPACA made healthcare systems more responsible for community wellness, raising hospital costs while limiting their revenue growth potential. The response from hospitals was to focus on cost reduction, which meant opting for renovation rather than new construction to improve efficiency at the lowest cost. An influx in out-patient centers has been detrimental to the industry, as not all out-patient clinics are tied to hospitals. The limitation in hospital capacity nationwide due to these market conditions led the nation to be woefully under capacity for the hospitalization needs associated with the pandemic. The emphasis on out-patient services has forced hospitals to reduce their capacity. Inpatient days and hospital admission have contracted faster than hospital employment and establishments. The decline in national hospital occupancy further highlights the mismatch in supply and demand. A surge in federal healthcare spending in response to the pandemic, with the need to expand hospital capacity becoming critical, has helped mitigate the negative influence of trending out-patient service.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: INDUSTRY PROFITABILITY WANES, BUT PANDEMIC WOES HAVE BEGUN TO GIVE WAY TO SHIFTING TIDES
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Excess inpatient capacity has remained an issue for hospitals, with small hospitals simply closing their doors to maintain profit. The discrepancy has also paved the way for more merger and acquisition activity, which has further limited demand for new hospital construction. The largest companies are often general contractors, such as Turner Construction Company and McCarthy Holdings Inc, even so, these two prominent companies account for an insignificant share of total industry revenue, heightening the industry's fragmented nature. Industry profit, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, has declined primarily due to stiff operating conditions caused by the pandemic and a generally poor performance during 2020.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Hospital Construction Companies Recover From the Disruptions That Plagued Them During the Height of the Pandemic
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Although new hospital construction will be driven by the gradual aging of the US population, effectively increasing demand for medical services, a more significant portion of this growth will go toward out-patient clinics. In the wake of the pandemic, the construction of excess hospital capacity and dedicated coronavirus wards are sure to be paramount, providing a much-needed revitalization to industry demand and revenue. Industry revenue will climb due to a surge in nonresidential construction activity, while total health expenditure continues to proliferate. Some positive highlights for the industry include focusing on ambulatory and out-patient facilities serving as hospital departments, which are more cost-effective. These facilities are a source of growth for industry enterprises, but also divert demand from new hospital construction, which are higher-value projects.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Lack of Clear Direction Leaves Hospitals Hesitant to Plan Future Capital Spending Projects
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Though less than in prior years, Lingering uncertainty over the future of US healthcare has caused providers to delay new construction major projects, which is unlikely to change anytime soon. Though the Biden administration has worked to undo some of the deregulation conducted by the Trump administration, this still represents a vacillation on a clear path forward and industry enterprises might be hesitant at best to commit to long-term projects. While uncertainty still lingers, industry enterprises will continue to construct out-patient clinics and off-hospital campuses to reach a larger population share. Federal spending on dedicated COVID-19 wards is anticipated to aid industry performance.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Gradual Aging of the US Population Will Continue to Be a Contributing Factor Driving Demand for Hospital Services
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: With a greater share of adults older than 65, demand for hospital services will rise. According to Architectural, Engineering and Construction Outlook, if the number of hospitals expands in line with the senior population over the next 20 years, an additional 2,000 hospitals and 340,000 hospital beds will likely be required. Hospital growth will likely lag behind the development of out-patient facilities, some of which are independently owned. According to the latest survey conducted by Health Facilities Management, hospitals surveyed said they planned to build more ambulatory and out-patient facilities rather than acute care hospitals soon. Due to improvements in healthcare technology, hospitals can treat more patients on an out-patient basis, which also tends to be more cost-effective. Future hospital construction will focus on providing smaller facilities and more multifunctional rooms to cut down on capital expenses. The cost to build out-patient facilities is far less than that to build hospitals. As demand for one rises, demand for the other wanes.

industry_definition: This industry includes operators that engage in new work, additions and reconstruction projects for both private and public hospital construction

mixed_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level medium - steady

key_trends: The emphasis on outpatient services has forced hospitals to reduce their capacity
Providers have delayed major construction projects to the detriment of operators
Industry operators have a diversified portfolio of construction projects
The repeal of the PPACA will likely be coupled with a decline in Medicaid spending
The gradual aging of the US population will likely be a contributing factor driving demand
Industry wages are expected to rise despite falling industry participation
Industry profit has risen marginally as hospital occupancy has risen

market_segmentation.segment_description: According to a 2021 American Hospital Association (AHA) survey, 2,978 of the 6,129 community hospitals polled are operated as nongovernment, nonprofit organizations. This figure includes more than 600 hospitals operated by religious organizations, collectively accounting for 55.5% of industry revenue in 2023.
There are also 1,235 investor-owned or for-profit community hospitals, accounting for 23.0% of industry revenue in 2023, making them the second-largest group of establishments.
According to the AHA survey, 944 state and local government community hospitals nationwide, accounting for 17.6% of industry revenue in 2023.
In 2023, the federal government is expected to account for 3.9% of industry revenue.

products_and_services.product_description: Industry participants operating as general contractors on the construction of new hospitals generate 61.3% of industry revenue in 2023.
Supplying construction alterations for hospital building projects generates 34.6% of industry revenue in 2023.
Hospital construction companies acting as maintenance contractors on existing buildings account for 4.1% of industry revenue in 2023.

tier_1_suppliers: Glass Product Manufacturing in the US
Heavy Equipment Rental in the US
Iron & Steel Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Healthcare and Social Assistance in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Health Expenditure and Hospital Space Demand
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Health expenditure and the need for more hospital space are expected to rise. Due to its large size, the baby boomer generation is the main driver for this growth.
Local, state, and federal government investment is an important indicator of success for hospital construction because much of the funding for new hospitals comes from government grants.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Interest Rates and Access to Credit
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Another critical factor to this industry's demand is interest rates, which generally influence demand for new construction because lower rates make financing new construction easier.
Stochastic events such as the pandemic can potentially boost demand since hospital capacity can be pushed into the critical zone, a worry and threat that remained throughout the pandemic.

international_trade_points.trade_description: The Hospital Construction industry is composed of companies that construct hospitals within the United States. There is no international trade within the industry because goods are not passed from one country to another.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region's share of establishments slightly outpaces its share of the US population, largely due to the constant need for new hospitals or expansions and renovations of existing hospitals. The Southeast is home to persistent health problems that stem from lifestyle factors, such as obesity, and a disproportionately high number of senior citizens living there.

California is the single most prominent location for the industry, accounting for the most establishments out of any state in the nation. Hospital construction companies are less inclined to be in rural areas in the US. This is because industry enterprises tend to gravitate toward more affluent areas, and hospitals in more rural areas typically serve more uninsured or low-income patients.
Other factors besides population including the population's age distribution, birth rates and household incomes enable the Great Lakes to be a burgeoning location for hospital construction.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Hospital Construction industry operates in a heavily regulated environment. The regulatory regime is steadily increasing as the clients, such as public sector agencies, healthcare companies and property developers, seek technologically advanced buildings and materials.

regulations_points.regulation_title: OSHA Standards for the Construction Industry
regulations_points.regulation_description: The standards for the construction industry are contained in Title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 1926. State and local building authorities assess and enforce this code.

A broad range of codes govern activity in this industry, including general building, residential, mechanical, plumbing, electric, fire, accessibility, zoning, state and local codes. The International Code Council endorses building codes.

Six major trade and professional associations have officially endorsed the American Institute of Constructors (AIC) Constructor Certification program, which qualifies individuals through education, experience and examination for the professional designations of Associate Constructor and Certified Professional Constructor.
As sustainable building continues to proliferate, the Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) certification is significant to this industry.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The regulatory regime is heavy and steadily increasing.
New entrants with limited financial resources and network will likely be excluded from participating in development consortiums.
New entrants find it difficult to establish foothold due to lack of reputation and proven performance.
Existing players have advantage of skilled subcontractors, supplier arrangements, financial ties.

basis_points.basis_description: The Hospital Construction industry exhibits highly competitive conditions within distinct class sizes. Many medium-scale contractors compete for a share of relatively narrow regional markets. Larger companies vie for a limited number of medium- to large-scale projects.

Competition among contractors is not solely based on pricing, but also on differentiation between contractors' proven track records for quality, efficiency, and timeliness. Selection is based on reputation and relationships for large projects.
Due to the nature of the industry, there is very little external competition.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry is fragmented with a low level of concentration. The largest company accounts for less than 2% market share.
The industry is dominated by subcontractors that compete locally/regionally, contributing to fragmentation.
The narrow scope of the industry decreases larger players' market share and concentration.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Material purchase costs account for an estimated 69.5% of industry revenue in 2023 and include ready-mix concrete, glass, structural steel or timber, plaster products, aluminum fittings, electrical and air-conditioning components, and elevators.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The Hospital Construction industry exhibits a low level of capital intensity and is highly labor-intensive. In 2023, for $1.00 dollar spent on labor, industry operators will spend an estimated $0.03 on capital investment.

volatility_points.volatility_title: THE HOSPITAL CONSTRUCTION INDUSTRY EXHIBITS A MODERATE LEVEL OF REVENUE VOLATILITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: - Regulatory uncertainty decreases demand for hospital construction and increases competition over existing project opportunities, putting downward pressure on pricing. - The industry has been able to moderate revenue volatility somewhat by completing smaller new construction projects and renovations.

volatility_points.volatility_title: THE PANDEMIC THRUSTS THE INDUSTRY INTO TEMPORARY DISARRAY
volatility_points.volatility_description: The pandemic served to exacerbate revenue volatility but the industry was able to recover and fulfill pent-up demand as global supply chains ease and prices cool off.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Technological advancements in construction management techniques, equipment and building materials for the Hospital Construction industry have significantly altered industry activities in recent decades.
There is a growing emphasis in the United States on designing energy-efficient hospitals that use sustainable materials and equipment for the job.
Better management techniques enable enterprises to identify deviations from the planning path quickly.

FAQs.question: How does your company hedge against an economic downturn?
FAQs.answer: Demand for hospital construction will typically follow the general business cycle. In economic downturn, countercyclical budgetary action will support demand for industry projects. However, it should be expanded up that overall, industry revenue will mostly follow trends in private capital expenditure, since private markets account for the majority of industry revenue.

FAQs.question: How does your company protect itself from market risk?
FAQs.answer: Specialized companies may have a superior reputation, increasing sales. Nondiversified companies may experience greater revenue volatility, hurting future earnings. Overall, companies that cater to a diverse range of downstream projects will be less volatile and less exposed to market risk.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in close proximity to buying and selling markets?
FAQs.answer: Companies located in proximity to upstream suppliers will exhibit lower purchase costs and greater profitability. Companies located not in proximity to end markets will have higher transportation costs, hindering profitability. The overall structure of the industry necessitates that operations be fragmented geographically since it is uncompetitive to be offering services outside a specific range.

FAQs.question: Has your company contended with volatile input prices?
FAQs.answer: Companies that enter into long-term supply agreements with suppliers can protect themselves from future input price increases, protecting themselves from upside risk.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging the latest technologies?
FAQs.answer: Companies using the latest technologies will exhibit higher operational efficiencies and wider profit. Drones have become a viable commercial technology for industry operators via the Federal Aviation Administration's legalization of using commercial drones. Overall, using them to scope out job sites, a heat map, and 3D models are some examples of using this labor-saving technology.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to reduce wage costs via technology?
FAQs.answer: Companies with the latest technologies will be more price-competitive due to labor cost savings. However, wage costs can be most easily reduced via the subcontracting of nonessential employees as well as only keeping specialized employees on the books full-time.

FAQs.question: Is your company prepared to meet shifting environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: Companies with an environmentally friendly reputation may be preferred by the public, increasing sales volumes. Noncompliant companies will be subject to fines and penalties, reducing profitability. With potential shifts to environmental regulations could cause industry operators to exhibit an increase in operating costs. More specifically since this is a publicly funded industry, public authorities may not be able to accept bids from non-compliant firms.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all occupational health and safety requirements are upheld?
FAQs.answer: Companies with a proven reputation for safety may be favored in the contract tender process. Noncompliant companies will exhibit insurance premium cost increases, reducing profit.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit margin compare to those of your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Companies using the latest technologies will have higher operational efficiencies and wider profit. Companies that engage in long-term supply management will have lower purchase costs and greater profitability. Companies must serve to differentiate themselves from their competition via a strong reputation for quality and under-budget projects. Since this is a publicly-funded industry, the least cost is of critical importance in order to win contracts.

FAQs.question: Does your company experience any difficulty financing current operations?
FAQs.answer: Most construction projects are financed by credit or debt and rising interest rates will inhibit borrowing to fund current operations. Countercyclical budget action by the federal government can increase funding in times of economic downturn. It is important to note that revenue from projects is not realized until after completion, requiring significant cash reserves and steady cashflow to see companies through periods of depressed demand.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in government regulations?
FAQs.answer: Since this industry is highly regulated, industry operators must be aware of all pertinent regulations at the local, state and national level to accurately and safely complete projects.

FAQs.question: Have you had any issues with government regulations in the past? How did you solve this problem?
FAQs.answer: Since this industry is highly regulated, industry operators must be aware of all pertinent regulations at the local, state and national level to accurately and safely complete projects.

FAQs.question: How hard is it to promote your company to suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Successful operators must have good relations with suppliers to secure favorable building material contracts.

FAQs.question: How can your company to receive better recommendations from other companies you work with?
FAQs.answer: Successful operators must have good relations with suppliers to secure favorable building material contracts.

FAQs.question: How do you make sure your prices are attractive to customers? How effective is your company at competing on tender?
FAQs.answer: Since many of this industry's consumers are public, not-for-profit agencies, being able to compete on price for contracts is paramount.

FAQs.question: How have fluctuations in local or state government funding affected your business? How do you keep tabs on these fluctuations?
FAQs.answer: Healthcare leaders have operated under a cloud of uncertainty since the introduction of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. While the regulation itself has had adverse effects on hospital occupancy rates over the past five years, the ongoing battle to repeal the act has tempered demand for new construction.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor funding levels for Medicare and Medicaid? Have you noticed whether demand for your company's services has increased or decreased as a result?
FAQs.answer: Increased public funding for Medicare and Medicaid helps subsidize healthcare costs for consumers, thereby raising demand for hospitals and, by extension, industry services.

FAQs.question: How does your company promote health expenditure?
How has total health expenditure fared since the recession?
FAQs.answer: Positive trends in disposable income, insurance coverage, medical improvements and the gradual aging of the US population increase demand for hospital services and, as a result, expansions and new hospital construction.
